texts.definition: Committing resources in a competition against others to determine who can make a specific purchase or trade.
markups: <style="Definition">Committing resources in a competition against others to determine who can make a specific purchase or trade.</style>

A <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> instance is a process consisting of several parts: the bidding where players invest resources with the hope to achieve an outcome, the determination of the outcome of these investments, and the distribution of possible rewards.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> and related games, players take turns on bidding on the value of their card hands. Players are part of those that can win as long as they match previous bids or increase the bid each time it's their turn, and players give up the bidding lose what they have bid. The player with the best hand of those left when everybody has stopped increasing the bids wins.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> provides players with four tokens each turn that are used to bid on a number of drawn cards, thereby supporting bidding on multiple rewards simultaneously. While the highest bidder gains the card bid on for the rest of the game, those that had bid less on that card gets a specific resources or possible action as compensation.

In the Game Theory two-player game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dollar%20Auction">Dollar Auction</link></style>, both players lose what they have bid, and this feature is used to show how localized rational behavior can lead to long-term irrational behavior.

Kicking out a player from an open game instance of team-based multiplayer games, e.g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style>, typically requires that a certain number of players have voted for kicking the player out.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

The basis for creating an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Auctions">Auction</link></style> or <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> activity is to have <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that players can use for bidding and some type of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> that can be gained by favourable outcomes of the bidding.

Two main categories for the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> are those that are used for other aspects of the game and those specifically dedicated for the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style>. Examples of other aspects can be those used for any other action dependant on <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, e.g., <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>, or those used as <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> is an example of a game using dedicated and <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> to ensure that players can participate in all the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> of the game. Having dedicated <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> makes it straightforward to create <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style> for how much <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> can be done, e.g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> provides 4 tokens each turn to each players, but by having dedicated <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that are <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> on can have global <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style> on how much <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> can be done. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Las%20Vegas">Las Vegas</link></style> let players roll <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style> on their turn and the results determine how players can bid and shows how <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can influence how players can bid; the dice used for bidding are committed until the end of the turn so the game also provides an example of how <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style> can influence <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style>.

<style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for successful bidding can be <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, but other possibilities are the ability to perform certain actions or receiving <style="Link"><link="first-player-tokens">First Player Tokens</link></style> and all these can be combined. When bidding <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> are also used for other gameplay aspects, the choice of having the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> bid be made into the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> handed out, as for example is the case with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>, and creates feedback loops (<style="Link"><link="positive-feedback-loops">Positive</link></style> for those winning as they can participate more in future <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> and <style="Link"><link="negative-feedback-loops">Negative</link></style> for those the lose) unless countered by other game mechanisms. Using only bid <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> makes the basis for having a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Closed%20Economies">Closed Economy</link></style> but of course requires that no ways of generating more <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> exist elsewhere in the game. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mammut">Mammut</link></style> inverts normal <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> in that each <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> activity starts with a randomly generated untaken set of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> is done turn-based by each player with no <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> either taking what he or she thinks is appropriate from the untaken <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or by taking all the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> of another player and returning at least one <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> to the untaken set.

How <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> are distributed can vary in <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> activities. Letting the winning bid gain the whole <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> is a simple option used for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>, but the total <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> may be split so runners-up gain some part of the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> provides one type of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> to the player winning the bid of a card but lets all other players that bid on the card get a temporary effect based upon how much they bid - this makes players place bids on cards with the goal of actually not wanting to win the bid since the temporary effects may be better for them. <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> are typically used in <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> to make <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> distributions clearer. Another way to handle <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> distribution is to allow players to bid on several different sets of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>. Both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Las%20Vegas">Las Vegas</link></style> does this, letting players make one bid on one set of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> each time it is their turn. By having some part of the offered <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> be unknown to the players can give the possibility to feel <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style>. If some players can have means of gain information regarding these <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, it creates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style> among the players which can make the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> more complex; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mammut">Mammut</link></style> is an example of a game with this form of <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style>.

Another aspect for creating <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> is setting up the rules on how bids can be done. <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> is often structured according to some form of <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> - this helps players engage in <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> and make <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> function - but it can also be done by letting all players bid whenever they wish. Typically, when there is only one thing to bid on bids need to increase each time (if the bidding activity is solely determined on how much is bid) or need to increase or match the highest bid (if the outcome of the bidding activity is based upon something else, e.g., player's hands in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style>). If several sets of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> can be bid on it is typical (see e.g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Las%20Vegas">Las Vegas</link></style>) to only allow bidding on one set each time it is a players turn. <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> on several sets can either allow players to choose with set to bid upon each time or require that the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> on one set is concluded before the next is started; the latter can still be seen as one common <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> activity if players need to make use of the same <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> for all the sets. As described above, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mammut">Mammut</link></style> shows a different type of <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> process where players have options on "Bidding" on either the untaken set of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or any of the "bids" other players have made. <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> can emerge in all types of <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> since players can make bids they actually don't want to succeed. However, <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> can be supported mechanically in the game through making players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style>, for example through letting players hide how much they bid. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Null%20Tokens">Null Tokens</link></style> can be used in these situations to let players pretend to bid when they are not or to let the number of tokens used to do bids not leak as much information as to what the bid actually is.

It is necessary to decide what bids are actually paid after <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> has changed. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> and other games where the bids make up the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> make all bids committed to being paid even if players change opinions during the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> and fold. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dollar%20Auction">Dollar Auction</link></style> provides a one dollar extra to the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> but otherwise functions equally. Games with specialized <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> typically require them to be paid also, even if they typically then are recycled to the players for another <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> activity; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Las%20Vegas">Las Vegas</link></style> both do this and in addition <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style> provides <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for all bids.

A final aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> is how to determine who wins what <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>. A straightforward solution is that whoever bid the most on a set of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> receives it, this is done for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Furnace">Furnace</link></style>. As mentioned earlier, <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> are often used to find a unique ordering of the bids - <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lag%20Vegas">Lag Vegas</link></style> is noteworthy here in that all tied bids are not considered making it possible in some circumstances to win a bid even if one has the least bid. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> and its offsprings such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style> make use of the value of players' <style="Link"><link="cards">Card</link></style> hands according to a point scale. Here, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style> between players make it uncertain who actually has the best hand until the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> is concluded - <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style> allows more informed speculation of other players' hands by letting some <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> be shared between all the players. The <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style> provides typically makes the ability to calculate the odds for various outcome a form of <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, so some forms of <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> support the presence of that pattern in this way. The way <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mammut">Mammut</link></style> works makes players receive <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> that they themselves has chosen and thereby should be quite satisfied with.
Alternatives to using <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> include <style="Link"><link="drafting">Drafting</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="token-placement">Token Placement</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> may spontaneously appear in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> if players have possibility to decide among themselves how to divide <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> they have acquired. When it does, it makes <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> a particular form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distribution%20of%20Rewards%20&%20Penalties">Player-Decided Distribution of Rewards & Penalties</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> is a form of <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>, although the <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style> it provides typically mainly comes from the uncertainty of how much players will bid. It is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> among players, most typically a <style="Link"><link="resource-competition">Resource Competition</link></style>, where winning bids provide <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> that typically are <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> but can relate to other things, e.g., <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>. This means that <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> can support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> through a form of <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> or can play the role of being <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bridge">Bridge</link></style> shows how <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> can modulate games regarding <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="trumps">Trumps</link></style> (rather than being a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style>), and here the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> can be seen as a way to determine which player may enforce a <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player-Defined Goals</link></style> on the game. Since <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> is won by eliminating all other players for wishing to bid or being able to bid, the goal of <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> can be seen has have an <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goal besides the typical <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> one. The also allows <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> to support the <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Role</link></style> of being a ''Dominators''.

Being an elective action, <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> provides players with a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> as long as they have enough <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> to be able to raise the bid. That the cost varies means that players can have to deal with <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> in that the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> used for bids may not be able to be used for other things and this can cause <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>. Handling these aspects typically requires players to engage in <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> requires several potential bidders, it is a way to provide a shared activity within <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. These activities are <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style> even if they are not cooperative and can be seen as a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>. When players are bidding not because they actually want to win the bid but rather force others to pay more, the <style="CurrentLink">Bidding</style> activity for those specific people become a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Push%20Your%20Luck">Push Your Luck</link></style> activity relying on <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>.
<style="H2">Relations</style>
<style="H3">Can Instantiate</style>

<style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distribution%20of%20Rewards%20&%20Penalties">Player-Decided Distribution of Rewards & Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player-Defined Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Push%20Your%20Luck">Push Your Luck</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-competition">Resource Competition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style>
<style="H4">with <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style></style>
<style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Modulate</style>

<style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trumps">Trumps</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Instantiated By</style>
<style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Modulated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Null%20Tokens">Null Tokens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>
<style="H3">Possible Closure Effects</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Potentially Conflicting With</style>
N/A
